Rishabh Mariwala

This is a sharp reminder that categories may attract capital, but they rarely create loyalty. Customers stay only when their real problems are solved.

Founders who anchor on people instead of labels end up building businesses that endure. The pitch room likes categories, but the market only rewards relevance.

Headline: CEO @ [Coming Soon] | Building Ecosystems, Not Just Startups | Designing Growth Engines Across Markets, Capital & People
Comment:
Chasing categories like quick commerce or D2C beauty just to impress investors? 
Classic startup fashion victim move. 

Here‚Äôs the real talk: your customer doesn‚Äôt give a damn about your ‚Äòhot‚Äô label; they care if your product solves their mess. 

The fresh POV: categories are like fashion trends; fleeting and often shallow; but real customers are forever stuck with their problems. So instead of building slides to woo VCs, build solutions that customers can‚Äôt ghost. 

Because at the end of the day, it‚Äôs product-market fit, not investor clout, that pays rent and fuels growth. Pro tip: stop chasing hype, start chasing real pain.

Categories are great for investors, but customers only care about whether their pain disappears. I‚Äôve seen this play out with friends building startups and with myself as well - got caught in the wave of ‚Äòhot sectors,‚Äô but when the buzz cooled, they were left trying to reverse-engineer a real user problem. Urban Company is one of the biggest example of solving pain first > creating category later.
